fields.description:
"git add --patch"  aka add --interactive fails with perl error

$ git add --interactive .                                                                               
C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\bin\perl.exe: *** couldn't commit memory for cygwin heap, Win32 error 0      
C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\bin\perl.exe: *** couldn't commit memory for cygwin heap, Win32 error 0      
           staged     unstaged path                                                                     
                                                                                                        
                                                                                                        
*** Commands ***                                                                                        
  1: status       2: update       3: revert       4: add untracked                                      
  5: patch        6: diff         7: quit         8: help                                               
What now> 7                                                                                             
Bye.                                                                                                    
                                                                                                        
                                         
$ git add --patch .                                                                                     
C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\bin\perl.exe: *** couldn't commit memory for cygwin heap, Win32 error 0      
C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\bin\perl.exe: *** couldn't commit memory for cygwin heap, Win32 error 0      
No changes.                                                                                             
                                                                                                        

$ git status
# On branch master
# Changes to be committed:
#   (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage)
#
#       modified:   .gitignore
#
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
#       modified:   .gitignore
#
fields.summary: "git add --interactive/--patch" from terminal fails

fields.description:
I have encountered the bug described in SRCTREEWIN-1011 in the current version of SourceTree (1.6.14).

'git log' failed with code 128: fatal: bad revision 'this is in square brackets' (C:\repository)

and the Log / History view is empty.
I can use the exact same steps described in SRCTREEWIN-1011 to reproduce it (and work around it by removing square brackets from the commit message).
The error occurs only if my local branch does not track a remote branch, I'm in the Current Branch view and Show Remote Branches is checked. If any of these conditions is not met, the Log displays fine.
fields.summary: 'git log' error 128 because of square brackets (SRCTREEWIN-1011)

fields.description: I'm just moving to Mercurial from SVN, taking the opportunity to structure my repo layouts better (well anything's better than the monolithic SVN repo we were using before). It's been difficult to determine what's Best Practice, but I'm currently evaluating and leaning towards having Dev, Test & Release repo's for each project (in addition to each developer's working repo). Thus the same project name could be in up to 4 tabs in the SourceTree window. I can assign repo's to folders in the navigation pane (which is really nice!), my suggestion is I think it'd be very useful to be able to colour-code the folder and/or tab backgrounds to help avoid confusion and possible errors...
fields.summary: Colour-code Tabs & Folders

fields.description: It would be great if we could copy text from the diff screen viewer
fields.summary: copying from the diff viewer

fields.description:
*A user said:*

"Let's assuming you have example.txt tracked in a mercurial repository...

Rename the file to Example.txt (let's assume you are working with a case-sensitive FS on the receiving end that clones down the repo and happen to require Example.txt). The include will fail due to missing file/folder errors. The workaround to this is to do two separate commits:

1. Move the renamed file to somewhere else. Commit.
2. Move the file back (the upper-cased letter name) back to its original location. Commit.
3. New file name (Example.txt, NOT example.txt) is detected and in repository as it should have been all along.

The workaround is fine; however, it is an unexpected inconvenience. I would expect when I make a change to the filename (including capitilization of any letter in its name) that the change would be detected and the repository updated with that change – even on a non-case sensitive FS like win8's.

So, to clarify... sourcetree is just not detecting the change file name. the third party system is just an example of how a linux machine would consume the repository.

If you were to ls in the directory the example.txt would be, it'll read, "example.txt" – indicative that sourcetree did in fact not detect the changed file name – and therefore assumed that nothing new was there to commit, nor was it able to be seen on the third party system (how I originally discovered this issue)."

---------

I've personally reproduced this; though Mercurial on Windows itself treats "Example.txt" or "example.txt" as the same file without any changes done. But if that particular change is done on Linux itself, Mercurial on Linux will treat it as different files. Hence, this might be a Mercurial on Windows problem rather than SourceTree.

This is a request for improvement on SourceTree's side instead - to help SourceTree on Windows to recognize case sensitivity.
fields.summary: Case sensitivity of file renames not respected in Windows

fields.description: After the most recent update (1.6.14), Source Tree fails to launch. I attempted to restart and that did not help. I attached a stacktrace from the log file.
fields.summary: Source Tree Fails To Launch

fields.description:
Crash on startup when viewing repos in certain states (or after certain operations)

*The repository in question contains a commit with a blank message* and I suspect this is probably a contributor to the crash
fields.summary: Crash on startup or after certain operations

fields.description:
# open network shared folder. In my case it's \\10.10.1.20\project
# put computer to sleep
# move to another location where the shared folder is not accessible
# SourceTree hangs and needs to be killed from TaskManager
# trying to start SourceTree again doesn't work
# SourceTree appears in TaskManager -> Details but no window is displayed

Workaround: manually remove the corresponding <TreeViewNode /> from user's
AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\bookmarks.xml
fields.summary: hangs on opened network shared folder after location change

fields.description: Right now, the Stash Changes dialog box has only one option, "Keep staged changes." Please add a second one: "Include untracked files," e.g., the equivalent (when checked) of *--include-untracked* on a *git stash save* command. I almost never want to stash changes without including untracked (e.g., new) files.
fields.summary: Add checkbox to include untracked files when stashing

fields.description:
# Click 'Tools'
# Pick 'Options' from drop down menu -> Options window opens
# Click on button named 'Mercurial'
# -> crash
fields.summary: crash when trying to open hg tab in options dialog

fields.description:
I wanted to clone a repostiry from Github but Sourcetree crashed.

# Click on button 'Clone / New'
# Find and click the tiny button icon button which has a earth icon on it
# -> crash
fields.summary: Crash when trying to browse remote hosted projects
Crash when maximising window

fields.description:
A user said, "We have multiple branch histories and, more importantly, several subtrees (incl. an upstream Pressflow Drupal distro, several modules, etc) which each have a long commit history. It's difficult to see where things connect with more than a few history lines on the screen, esp. if there is a long list of commits (e.g. in ancestor order). 
What I am thinking would be useful is the ability to "toggle" visibility of these history lines by branch, or perhaps even by an unnamed subtree merge.

I would like to toggle visibility of subsets of branches, not just view a single branch in isolation with the existing functionality"

!toggle.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Feature Request: The ability to "toggle" visibility of these history lines by branch, or perhaps even by an unnamed subtree merge.

fields.description:
Use case 1:
1. Open SourceTree
2. Clone remote repository
3. SourceTree crashes after repo copied, before opened in right pane, repo view

Use case 2:
1. Open SourceTree
2. Double click repo in right pane, tree view
3. SourceTree crashes before succeed to show repo in right pane, repo view. 

Log added for second use case.
fields.summary: Crashes moment after repository opening

fields.description:
The pull number should disappear after pull is done, because there are no other commits in the upstream. The bug is that it doesn't, the number is still displayed. If I click the pull button again, the window with the text "No changes to pull" appears. I click "Ok" but the number on the pull button is still there.

The similar behavior happens with the push button. When I push e.g. 3 commits to the remote repository, the number should disappear, but it doesn't. The number 3 is still displayed on the button.

This is confusing. A user assumes that he/she pulls all the changes from the remote repository, but SourceTree says that remote repository still has some changes. The same with the push. The user pushes his/her commits to the remote repository, but SourceTree says that there are still some changes to be pushed.

Please, remove the number immediately after the action is done.
fields.summary: Pull/Push numbers appearance

fields.description: When cloning a wiki repo from our private repo the system crashed and generated the attached error log.  The actions I had taken were to go to the wiki in BitBucket and press clone in Source Tree, then went to Source Tree and tried to clone the request as a new repository on the local machine.  Source tree was not running at the time I tried the clone.  I was able to then open Source tree and get to the clone.
fields.summary: System crashed upon cloning a Wiki Repo

fields.description: In at least one of my repositories, the circle in the branch graph indicating which branch a commit belongs to is sometimes incorrect.  I have no idea how to reproduce this, I just noticed it when reviewing some history.  In the two Sourcetree screenshots, notice that the commits highlighted are in different branches - you can see this in the detail information below.  One is in "3.8" and the other in "experimental", which branches from the previous "3.8" commit.  However, in the graph view, they are both shown on the same branch, "3.8".  I've also attached a screenshot of TortoiseHg, which displays the commits on the correct branches.
fields.summary: Incorrect branch indicator in graph

fields.description:
I did a merge and got a conflicted file. I then edit the file to the way I want it, But Source Tree does not show the change. If I re-commit , the conflicted file still has the conflict lines. My change is not shown and is not shown as a modified file.
I reset my branch back before the merge and did the merge again. But this time before committing i used the terminal window to add my changed file. Source Tree still did not show this change. I did the commit and now Source Tree shows my change.
fields.summary: Conflict resolution does not stage file changes

fields.description: Just finished a merge conflict like i've done many times before and it crashed. so here's a log for ya!
fields.summary: Sourcetree crash during merge (post resolving a conflict)

fields.description:
On Windows 8.1 64-bit, I tried to create a new Git repository in the folder path: C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\cADFS. This is the official folder path where PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC) resources are stored, hence why I'm trying to write to this directory.

Most, if not all, folders underneath the Program Files directory are protected by Access Control Lists (ACLs), preventing non-admins from writing to it. Hence, when Source Tree is running as non-admin, it does not have permission to write to the directory. In this scenario, Source Tree crashes, instead of prompting the user for privilege elevation.

If you launch SourceTree under an administrative UAC token, it does not crash in this scenario.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when writing to folder without permissions

fields.description:
In my repository, I have files containing french-accented characters (not in the file name).

In SourceTree, the charcaters are replaced with a question mark in a black lozenge.

I used TurtoiseHg, and with it the content of the files were OK
fields.summary: Bad display of accented characters

fields.description:
It would be nice to have the "No Proxy" configuration option in the network settings, under the proxy server settings.

Right now, on the company I work for, we have Blue Coat for web proxy, but not all local servers are in the proxy script (an IT organization issue I know), so sometimes it forces us to go through the proxy even if the servers are on the local network.

Most applications have a "No Proxy" option, so it just tries to connect locally bypassing any proxy settings, but because SourceTree forces me to use either the system proxy settings or a manually entered proxy, there is no way for me to connect correctly to our local Git server. As we're using Netbeans, all fetch/pull/push operations are done through it, so we're using Sourcetree pretty much just as a Git browser, this sucks as it's a pain to work with Git like this.

I hope you soon add that feature, this will really help us work as expected.
fields.summary: Add a "No Proxy" option on the proxy server settings

fields.description: SourceTree in newest version show line numbers badly. If you take look on file changes, line numbers on left side showed good (1 - n). On right side only 1 - 100 a then continue with number 1 (to 100 ...)
fields.summary: SourceTree line numbers
Source Tree keeping Lag and Crash

fields.description:
Updated the .gitignore file (via repository settings menu option) on a repository (which allowed more files through).

Went to the branch view and clicked on the 'Uncommited Changes' line in order to stage the new allowed files.

Nothing appeared, so went back and checked .gitignore again, saw nothing wrong with it so cancelled out.

Clicked on 'Uncommited Changes' again and Sourcetree crashed.
fields.summary: Updated .gitignore, clicked 'Uncommited Changes', Sourcetree crashed.

fields.description:
The auto refresh make using the GUI problematic.
When I have two commits selected and I am comparing the differences the auto refresh from the repo deselects everything in the GUI and I have to start over.

The auto refresh also changes the view sizes to some default again interfering in my usage.

The auto refresh should not change anything in the GUI that is not related to data having been removed or deleted.
Presumably the auto refresh is checking the remote repo and not my local repo.
If anything changes in the remote repo this is no reason to change the contents or current configuration of the GUI.
I see no reason for an auto refresh checking my local repo.

This behavior is exceptionally annoying.
Enough so that if it is not corrected I will be finding another solution.
fields.summary: Auto refresh interferes with usage

fields.description: As I was preparing a commit, Sourcetree was not moving the files to the stage. I was confused by this... started clicking around and then SourceTree crashed (I'm not sure exactly how I did it).
fields.summary: Crashed when preparing a commit

fields.description:
Finding single files within sourcetree is imposible.

A new tab called "*File Tree*" together with "File Status" "Log/History" "Search" would be a major improvement. 

In this view it should be possible to filter by file status, that includes viewing files that are 
# Unchanged
# Modified
# Staged
# Staged & Modified
# Added
# Added & Modified
# Deleted
# Untracked

Additionally on top of that filtering of file type should be possible.

The tab could be split in tow where one half is the tree view itself and the other is the log/blame view for the selected file.
fields.summary: File Tree View Tab

fields.description: When I backed out a non-parent (but ancestor) changeset in a Mercurial repository, SourceTree created a temporary head from the changeset that is to be backed out and merged the new head with the current head. It is generally not necessary in Mercurial repositories and redundant. Just use 'hg backout' if possible.
fields.summary: Do not create a temporary head when backing out a changeset in Mercurial repositories

fields.description:
At the moment if we enable display of remote branches, and given the fact we may use feature numerous branches, we could endup with the long list of hardly distiguishable labels:

!sourctree-labels.png|thumbnail!

Could you please introduce color coding so we could distinguish local from origina here?
fields.summary: Color coded local/remote tags/branches

fields.description:
Created local branch, pushed to remote branch with slightly different name. Worked on local branch which was tracking remote, added two commits, used default push to remote (which doesn't use the previously specified name, i.e. pushed to a different branch (created one) than the one it was tracking), and SourceTree crashed.

Log attached.
fields.summary: Crash on push

fields.description:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/13411631/since-last-windows-update-sourcetree-wont-load-exception-0xc0000409

Basically, sourcetree.exe stopped loading, leaving an entry in event log saying faulting module d3d9.dll

*Work Around*
However, I was able to work around it by copying d3d9.dll into the sourctree folder, which is odd, because I have verified the \windows\system32 version is not corrupt (compared to the winsxs version), and the version now in the sourcetree folder is exactly the same checksum (both md5 and sha256), size and permissions as the one in \windows\system32
fields.summary: sourcetree does not load, faulting module d3d9.dll

fields.description:
I am unable to install SourceTree on my Windows 8 machine. I receive the attached error, even after a fresh restart, and ensuring that no installation processes are running in the background.

I've tried running the installation as an administrator and normally with no luck.

Please help!
fields.summary: Installation error - "Another instance of setup is already running"

fields.description:
# Make some changes in your working copy of a repo.  Don't commit.
# Perform an Hg Flow action, such as starting a feature
# The branch is not created and everything is left in the same state, but there is no error message.
# Commit your changes
# Perform the same Hg Flow action
# The action completes successfully

I have seen this with multiple mercurial repositories, none of which originally used hg-flow.  I have seen it happen with multiple different hg flow actions, it does not seem to matter which one you do.
fields.summary: Hg flow actions with working copy changes silently fail

fields.description:
I started SourceTree and (and the PassPhrase box to connect to the remote repository came up behind.   I moved SourceTree (after having committed some source changes) and instead of entering the passphrase, I clicked the X box to close the passphrase window, but then when I closed and restarted SourceTree,  I did not get a new dialog to enter the passphrase.  When I tried to push my committed changes, it couldn't connect to the remote repository (not unexpected),  but I could not figure out a way to get the passphrase dialog back from within SourceTree, and closing and reopening SourceTree did not work.  
I didn't see any background SourceTree-related process to kill (though I might have missed this).
The only way I found to correct this was to reboot my computer so there was a brand new computer session and launch SourceTree and enter the passphrase.

 I know that under normal operations when active, the underlying connection to the remote remains even if you start and stop SourceTree, and so I suspect that this is related, but it's annoying that when no connection exists, it can't detect this or at least have some way to reestablish the connection easily from within the application.
fields.summary: Closing passphrase box leaves you disconnected from remote with no way to reconnect except rebooting computer.

fields.description:
A customer said: "The name of this action 'discard file', always requires me to think if that is what I want to do. 'discard changes' might be more straight forward." I think his comment makes sense:

!discardwin.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Request to change "Discard File" option name, to "Discard Changes"

fields.description: Currently cmd window runs and stays open when complete.  Takes a few seconds to realise that operation is complete and Close is now enabled.  Could we add an option to "Close console output on success", perhaps just under (or over) "Always display full console output" in the Options->General tab?
fields.summary: Add option to auto-close command window on success

fields.description: Open SourceTree from Windows Explorer context menu when right-clicking on repo root.  Selected repo is then opened in SourceTree.  Repo could also be auto-added as bookmark if not already.
fields.summary: Windows explorer integration

fields.description:
# Opened SourceTree
# Cloned a repo (uninitialized)
# Added Moodle codebase 
# Staged files
# Committed files
# Added a tag
# Clicked the Push button
# Push dialogue box opened - I checked the "Push?" checkbox for master
# SourceTree crashed
fields.summary: Crash while preparing to push initial code base to origin

fields.description:
A user's Date Order view on SourceTree and {{git log --graph --all --date-order}} view on the command line has a slight difference; in SourceTree, the parent ancestry is not represented correctly, while in Git it is shown correctly:

!git-log.png|thumbnail!

!git-log2.png|thumbnail!

Also a detail to note: the two commits was done in just a few seconds in between each other, and that might be the reason SourceTree got mixed up.
fields.summary: Sourcetree Date Order ancestry incorrect

fields.description: When trying to add a folder to SourceTree by dragging in the symlink I am unable to do so. Attached is a screenshot which highlights this problem.
fields.summary: Symlinks not supported

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce: 
Start with a large repository
Choose the Log / History context
At the bottom of the screen it shows the recent additions. Right click on any of the files, and click around for a bit, and see it crash.
fields.summary: Crash when right clicking on file

fields.description: When you start a pull request from a remote repository, and the pull is significant enough to take a while, and you switch branch while git is still pulling, the pull data will be merged into a different branch (the one you checked out while performing a pull). It would be good idea if a lock can be produced from SourceTree to prevent such operations.
fields.summary: Prevent or lock Git operations when performing Pull

fields.description:
Currently only has Browse File System button (...)
Would be convenient if it matched Clone Repository SourcePath/Url functionality
fields.summary: Add Submodule:  Please add "Browse Hosted Projects" button to SourcePath/Url

fields.description:
When working with git-svn repositories it would be nice if the "Add New Remotes..." option would recognize local SVN repositories.
This would allow a developer who wants to work with the git-svn bridge to use the SVN repository stored on the local windows files system to init-clone-fetch the initial (often very large) repository.  Ours is 1.5 GB.  After that linking to the remote/web SVN repository would be for day2day interactions.

At the moment when you add local folder paths, it only detects the .git repositories, while it should check for SVN and then use the git-svn commands for working with that repository.

Further enhancements to the Git-SVN bridge would be to include UI options to allow further command line options, specific to Git-svn to be configured for those repositories.
fields.summary: Remote Repository - detect local SVN repositories

fields.description: Check box to perform "force" (--force) push in a push dialog.
fields.summary: "force" option for push

fields.description:
Both BitBucket and GitHub support emoji's in their commit messages. I think it would be a welcome addition to Sourcetree to display them and popup an autocomplete box of emoji when a {{:}} is typed.

[BitBucket emoji|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Can+I+use+markup+in+commit+messages?continue=https%3A%2F%2Fconfluence.atlassian.com%2Fdisplay%2FBITBUCKET%2FCan%2BI%2Buse%2Bmarkup%2Bin%2Bcommit%2Bmessages&application=cac]
[GitHub emoji|https://guides.github.com/features/mastering-markdown/#GitHub-flavored-markdown]
fields.summary: Support emoji in commit messages.

fields.description:
Running sourcetree 1.6.14.0 on Windows 8.1

I'm trying to add a subtree to a repo.

The progress bar starts running, but that's it. No message, error, no nothing, just running progress bar for ... ever?
fields.summary: Adding a subtree to a repository does nothing.

fields.description:
Under Git Flow > Other Action... > Finish Hotfix.

Hotfix's tag message appeared as the hotfix branch name {{new_hotfix}} instead of the intended message which is {{hotfix done}}:

!hotfix.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: "Finish hotfix" tag message doesn't work, instead copied hotfix branch name for the tag.

fields.description:
My pull button on toolbar in Sourcetree shows that I have to pull 39 commits from the remote repository - which CANNOT BE TRUE, since I'm the only developer within this project and I am sure, this cannot be true ... 
There are also 28 commits to push - Which IS true

Pressing the pull button nothing happens - no pull / merge takes place, the pull button still shows 39 commits to pull...
Within command shell I used the command _git fetch --dry-run_ which does not show any commits to be pulled on a real git fetch ... I also verified that there's nothing to pull by performing a pull using TortoiseGit.

How can I get rid of Sourcetree permanently displaying the fake neccessity of pulling 39 commits???
fields.summary: Pull (in Toolbar) displays wrong number of commits to pull

fields.description: I had made some changes to some files in a directory using Visual Studio 2013. After closing VS, I went to SourceTree to commit my changes.  The staged files and unstaged files were both empty.  I unchecked the Staged files checkbox, and the application crashed.
fields.summary: Application crashed when unchecking Staged Files checkbox

fields.description:
When open "create patch" window, it is not resizeble, and control bulltons is hidden and not avalilbe.

!SourceTree.jpg|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Trouble with medium font and low screen resolution

fields.description: The very common use case is to cherry-pick several sequential commits. Some kind of rebase. Wish to select several commit with ctrl+click ant cherry-pick them onto the top of selected branch.
fields.summary: Bucket cherrypick

fields.description: In interactive rebase from the chain of squashed commits only two first squashes. Workaround: do interactive rebase 100500 times.
fields.summary: Suquash does not squashes all required commits.

fields.description: SourceTree is very slow. I've got ~11 branches in "branthes" folder and ~260 in "remotes". Everythis is slow: files staging (check box selecting handled very slow), view update when selecting or switching the branch, views update on commit selection.
fields.summary: SourceTree is very slow

fields.description:
I have a folder named "secret_test", which contains 2 bookmarks:

!bookmarkbug.png|thumbnail!

Now I've created a new bookmark for a local repository also named "secret_test":

!bookmarkbug2.png|thumbnail!

Then I drag that new bookmark into that folder, and the folder disappeared along with the 2 other bookmarks:

!bookmarkbug3.png|thumbnail!

This is a screencast vid from a user who first found this bug: http://screencast.com/t/ZEUzs5tT
fields.summary: SourceTree Windows bookmark folder disappears if an empty repo bookmark got dragged into it.

fields.description:
Steps prior to crash:
# Updated SourceTree to new 1.6.14 version 
# File -> Clone/New -> Add Working Copy
## Wanted to upload a working copy into SourceTree I had cloned through Netbeans
# Working copy was successfully load, but wasn't up to date with Remote (Stash) repo
## it seemed to be getting the changes from Stash when it crashed:
{code}
2015-03-05T09:35:45: Fatal error: 
System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.

2015-03-05T09:35:45: Stack trace: 
   at SourceTree.Model.FileStatusRecord.Equals(Object obj) in c:\projects\atlassian.com\dev\bitbucket.org\sourcetreewin\Model\FileStatusRecord.cs:line 180
   at System.Collections.Generic.ObjectEqualityComparer`1.Equals(T x, T y)
   at System.Collections.Generic.HashSet`1.AddIfNotPresent(T value)
   at SourceTree.Utils.ViewHelper.ExpandedFileRecords(IEnumerable`1 fileTree) in c:\projects\atlassian.com\dev\bitbucket.org\sourcetreewin\Utils\ViewHelper.cs:line 212
   at SourceTree.Utils.ViewHelper.ExpandedFileRecords(IEnumerable`1 fileTree) in c:\projects\atlassian.com\dev\bitbucket.org\sourcetreewin\Utils\ViewHelper.cs:line 213
   at SourceTree.Utils.ViewHelper.ExpandedFilePaths(IEnumerable`1 fileTree) in c:\projects\atlassian.com\dev\bitbucket.org\sourcetreewin\Utils\ViewHelper.cs:line 183
   at SourceTree.ViewModel.ChangeSets.CommitChangeSetViewModel.<RefreshForCommit>d__2b.MoveNext() in c:\projects\atlassian.com\dev\bitbucket.org\sourcetreewin\ViewModel\ChangeSets\CommitChangeSetViewModel.cs:line 346
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.AsyncMethodBuilderCore.<ThrowAsync>b__0(Object state)
   at System.Windows.Threading.ExceptionWrapper.InternalRealCall(Delegate callback, Object args, Int32 numArgs)
   at MS.Internal.Threading.ExceptionFilterHelper.TryCatchWhen(Object source, Delegate method, Object args, Int32 numArgs, Delegate catchHandler)
{code}

I restarted SourceTree and noticed that master is 14 behind remote.
fields.summary: Crash on refreshing repository graph and descriptions

fields.description: When editing a Stash hosting account, although the "Projects to include" list contains all the projects visible to me, I cannot select more than one and even selecting one appears to have no effect on the list displayed in the Hosted Repositories window.
fields.summary: Edit Hosting Account for Stash does not allow selection of projects to include

fields.description:
In the branches view, at file list below the graph, the file selections and scrolling position auto refreshes on random time. Even if in the middle of selecting files, everything just randomly being refreshed. Sometimes it refreshes in a few seconds, sometimes it refreshes in minutes:

In the middle of selecting files while scrolling:
!sourcetreebug1.PNG|thumbnail!

Randomly it refreshed back:
!sourcetreebug2.PNG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: File selections and its scroll position in branches view fully refreshes midway

fields.description:
H!
Cool tools! But some bugs is there.

not displayed correctly encoding windows cp-1251

!attachment-name.jpg|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Wron display Windows CP-1251

fields.description:
Sometimes the files shown in the Log/History tab don't appear in the File Status tab under Pending files.
Even selecting/checking the files in the Log/HIstory tab, right clicking and selecting commit doesn't show them in the File Status tab.
When the files aren't shown in the File Status tab, it is still possible to click on the top check-box (to select all files) and do a commit.  This will result in all files being committed successfully.
There doesn't seem to be any pattern to how this happens as it happens at random times.
fields.summary: Files don't appear in File Status tab

fields.description:
Cloning a repository = CRASH
Creating new repository = CRASH
Adding a working copy path = CRASH

Restarting the app just renders the previous action's bookmark to be missing.
fields.summary: Crash at any initial action

fields.description:
Steps:
1- I clicked on Clone / New
2- I entered in Source Path: http://git.itx.com/quality-assurance/automation-framework.git
3- Destination Path was generated and I was prompted to authenticate for git.itx.com
4- I entered my username and password
5- Clicked Login
6- I was asked for password again (it didn't recognize it)
7- Clicked Cancel and exited from Clone / New screen
8- I went to Tools -> Options

Observed Results:
a- My Git credentials were not recognized in SourceTree. I also tried to logout and login again in Git and it worked, so it was no typo from my end.
b- The application crashed on step 8 above (see attachments). It seems to be related to the login issue, because I'm able to access to Options as long as I don't try to enter credentials in Clone / New.
fields.summary: Git credentials not recognized when creating repository, then crashes when entering to Options

fields.description:
As with GitFlow I would like to have the ability to add a tag when closing the release and apply it. I would like to have the option to tag before the close of the release so the tag will move to default and develop branch too. Since we use tags for versioning dlls this is really usefull.
If this option is implement in the HgFlow it would be nice to be ported into the GitFlow
fields.summary: Ability to add a tag when closing a release with HgFlow

fields.description: As with Git I would like to have the option to add a message to the tag. At the moment it creates a common message related to the previous commit.
fields.summary: Ability to add message to tag in mercurial

fields.description:
When selecting files to be committed, the check-box at the top of the file list (beside the list options drop-down) will check/uncheck the check-box of all files.

There is no way to check/uncheck a selection of files without going through them all individually.

It would be good if you could select all of the files you want to check/uncheck and then clicking on the check-box of any of those files would check/uncheck all files selected.
fields.summary: Multiple checkbox toggle

fields.description:
If I go Actions->Apply Patch ...
and select the patch below SourceTree crashes. This is reproducible.

The patch was created by TortoiseSVN, but SourceTree still shouldn't crash on it.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when trying to Apply a patch

fields.description:
If walk through the files I'm about to commit with the arrow keys, every time I move one down, the internal dif viewer starts reloading, If I press "down" 5 times, the dif view will reload 5 times, which takes quite a lot of time, and only then the UI responds to new input.

If you would delay updating the internal dif viewer with just 300ms (and reset that timer if another file is selected again) you could walk through the files quickly and only get a little UI hangup once you stand still on 1 file.

This would be quite an easy fix, and probably solve 80% of the current sluggishness I experience in sourcetree from day to day.
fields.summary: easy fix to improve speed - delay updating internal dif viewer with 300ms

fields.description: I am working with a project that uses a single subrepository. I had made various changes to files in the main and sub repositories, then remembered that I have been using HgFlow for new features. I decided to shelve the changes to allow me to start a new feature with HgFlow. When I shelved the changes, the main repository changes were shelved, but the changes to the subrepository were lost, and I cannot seem to find any record of them.
fields.summary: Shelving changes results in loss of subrepository changes

fields.description:
I am having trouble pushing files, it keeps popping up the error below.
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false push -v --tags origin master:master
Pushing to https://dalanis@stash.silabs.com/scm/lab_equipment/bldg200_4thfloor_lab_equipment_checkout.git

fatal: Authentication failed for 'https://dalanis@stash.silabs.com/scm/lab_equipment/bldg200_4thfloor_lab_equipment_checkout.git/'
fields.summary: not allowing me to push files

fields.description: Today you can select if you want to show remote branches or not in the Log/History view. Sometimes it is helpfull to be able to see local branches and branches from a specific remote but not from others.
fields.summary: It should be possible to see a subset of remotes in the tree view/history

fields.description:
SourceTree crashes if there's at least one repository in the list, before rendering the main panel.

See attachments for GUI status and log. It looks like it crashes due to an existing file (2015-03-03T11:30:19: Fatal error: 
System.IO.IOException: File esistente.)

I performed many clean installation from scratch, deleting files in Atlassian and Atlassian_Xyz folders under Local app data but it didn't solved the problem.
fields.summary: SourceTree keeps crashing just before rendering the main content area.

fields.description: Souretree crashes every time, when I like to open a repository. It doesn't matter if this is a big or small repo.
fields.summary: Crashing every time when opening repositories

fields.description:
SourceTree doesn't support force push. This is a very common requirement for OSS contributions where people require you to rebase your branch after a code review with a clean history for Pull Requests. 

Force push is intentionally not supported https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/54469 because of its hazard of overwriting other peoples changes and I am not asking for that.

There is a safer force push option available _*--force-with-lease*_ http://git-scm.com/docs/git-push that checks if *no one else has pushed after your pull then your rebase is okay to force push*. Would be great if this was supported.
fields.summary: A safe force push

fields.description: I can't open up a project because source tree keeps failing. I can use git normally in the folder and I've reinstalled git.
fields.summary: Crash on startup/switch to a branch

fields.description:
Since updating to 1.6.14, the _File Status_ view no longer automatically refreshes (and also doesn't refresh when pressing F5). However, switching to _Log/History_ and then back refreshes the list of pending changes.

I have the status view on _Pending Files, sorted by file status_.
fields.summary: File Status tab not updating

fields.description:
When developing I sometimes want to view a commit within SourceTree in a browser window so I can comment on it.

Could a right-click option be provided (e.g. "Open in browser" or "Open on BitBucket") that can open the appropriate page so I don't have to copy the SHA and paste it onto the end of a web address.

Relates to SRCTREEWIN-1380
fields.summary: Be able to open commit in browser (BitBucket website)

- Rename/delete directory %APP_DATA%\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree.exe_Url_(some weird string) or,
- Delete all files in C:\Users\Michael\AppData\Local\Temp or,
- Rename the file %APP_DATA%\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\<date>_<hash>.txt then start Sourcetree

fields.description:
setting "Create a new commit even if fast-forward is possible" is not remembered. Possible solutions:
- pull dialog remembers last used settings
- make default settings for this dialog configurable
fields.summary: "Pull dialog", Setting "Create a new commit even if fast-forward is possible"

fields.description:
Open up a repo using the windows version, right click a folder you want to ignore -> ignore 

EXPECTED: the 'ignore under this path' radio button is selected
ACTUAL: top radio button is selected
fields.summary: When right-click a folder->ignore, default to 'files under this path'

fields.description:
In the Log/History view, I want to have a checkbox saying "First Parent Only" (maybe right next to the "Show Remote Branches" checkbox item). When checked, The log view will use the --first-parent flag. I would expect, then, to see only a single line of history for a branch. If multiple branches are being shown (eg. the "All Branches" option), then if the two branches intersect, they will intersect in the Log view as well. When the "First Parent Only" option is not checked, the Log view will behave as before.

This should be exactly like using `git log --graph --first-parent`

The reason I marked it as Major is because this issue is not "Trivial". In an ideal world, everyone knows everything about git and they don't need the GUI to show only first parent. However, I am in a company that is huge and has many, many different people of different paradigms and skills, and as people start switching to git, one of the main points of confusion (and continual frustration and confusion) is that the Log view is chaotic and hard for them to use.
fields.summary: 'First Parent Only' option

fields.description:
Very often (i.e. not in 100% of cases) when I switch between branches all difference between them are marked as modified and some of them are placed in staged area.

I noticed that it happens when I use next post-checkout hook:

{code:none}
#!/bin/sh

echo "Executing POST-CHECKOUT hook script"

# NOTE:
# Parameter $3 values:
#    0 - file checkout (reverting local file changes)
#    1 - branch checkout (switching between branches)
 
if [ $3 = 1 ]; then
	echo "Recursively removing bin/obj folders..."
	rm -rf `find . -type d \( -name "bin" -o -name "obj" \)`
	echo "DONE"
fi
{code}

It executes quite long since we have big project. Switching between branches using git command-line or TortoiseGit never gives the same problem. Without post-checkout hook it also works well.
So, seems the problem in SourceTree itself.
fields.summary: Checkout and post-checkout script

fields.description:
If I add a Submodule and specify a Source Branch in the Advanced Options, I get the following error:
  fatal: Cannot update paths and switch to branch '<BranchName>' at the same time.

Performing the operation a second time gives the illusion of it being a success, but in actual fact, one must do a manual checkout on the submodule folder to switch to the designated branch/tag...
fields.summary: Adding submodule with source branch always results in an error

fields.description:
If I right-click on a submodule and delete it, the submodule expandable disappears and only .gitmodules is updated.  I have to manually delete the submodule folder and stage it before the expandable reappears.

Ah, but if I delete the folder and stage, .gitmodules is updated and everything works as expected...
fields.summary: Submodule delete bug

fields.description: A feature that would be really helpful in improving the history view would be to display local commits (ones that have yet to be pushed to a remote repo) with a different icon. (a square? diamond?) instead of a circle.
fields.summary: Display public vs local commits differently in history graph

fields.description: A feature that would really help improve understanding in the history pane is to display "graphs" and transplant operations differently (dotted line rather than solid line?)
fields.summary: Graph shows graphs differently than normal history.

fields.description: A very useful visual element to the graph would be to display branch close commits differently than the typical circle icon. (A terminus icon of some sort)
fields.summary: Graph view shows branch closes visually

fields.description:
Everytime i start SourceTree it just crashes.
WIll remove repo.
fields.summary: Can't open source tree within repository

fields.description: Was cloning a project from a stash account with ssh.
fields.summary: Crashed on clone

fields.description: I selected a bunch of items then clicked "unstage changes" and then tried to ctrl+click 3 items out of a subfolder and it crashed.
fields.summary: Crash when selecting files

fields.description:
For more than one project SourceTree does not list untracked files in the Unstaged files list.  I can use the terminal and git status to see the untracked file.  I confirmed that nothing in the .gitignore would ignore the files.  The projects' full path has a space in it, but their relative paths do not.

If I use git add in the terminal to add the untracked files, they then appear in the staged area of SourceTree.  If in SourceTree I uncheck the staged, new file, the file is not moved to untracked under unstaged files.  This occurs for files in the root of the project and in subfolders that have other tracked files.
fields.summary: Untracked files not appearing in unstaged file list

fields.description:
When selecting files into "Unstaged files" view by pressing SpaceBar key to move them into "Staged files", then focus goes to main window. Next, pressing arrow keys cause moving into main window menu.

When pressing SpaceBar focus should remain into same view to allow other files to select by keyboard without need to use mouse.
fields.summary: Remain focus on "Unstaged files" view when selecting files for staging by keyboard (Space).

fields.description: I was checking the status of the submodules of the mkpusa.org website. I clicked on "Stage files" and the code went poof. All logs and a screen image are attached.
fields.summary: Click on Staged Files when there aren't any and... POOF!

fields.description:
After installing SourceTree I chose not to clone any repositories. Later I went in to get one of my hosted repositories. The hosted repositories were shown 3 times each in the list, and when I presased the [Edit accounts] button, I saw that my account was added 3 times.

After deleting the extra entries, my list of hosted repositories looks normal.
fields.summary: Multiple of the same account added

fields.description: SourceTree cost 50 seconds to start up when no internet connection available.
fields.summary: slow startup when no internet connection

fields.description: Applying patch causes crash
fields.summary: Crash when attempting to apply patch

fields.description:
Visual Studio Online's git repositories are case sensitive.  Occasionally someone creates a branch with the first letter upper case, such as "Feature/homepage".  When I pull this branch is SourceTree, the local branch name appears as "feature/homepage".  When I push changes to VSO, SourceTree pushes the lower case name and VSO creates a new branch that is all lower case.  Then we have two branches with the same name, only separated by case.   SourceTree still only shows one branch (the lower case one) and gives an error when trying to push to it again.  

I would like SourceTree for Windows to recognize and preserve the case, whatever it may be.
fields.summary: SourceTree ignores case of remote branch, and lowers the case on push

fields.description:
SourceTree was crashing on startup continuously with following error:

2015-02-24T10:20:46: Fatal error: 
System.IO.IOException: The file exists.

Removed bookmarks and open tabs allowed SourceTree to start, but as soon as reopen repository, app crashes with the same error.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashing

fields.description:
Started application with yesterday cloned braches in SourceTree, after closed application, and deleted locally tracked files from SSD, again starting application, and app crashes.


Crash report attached
fields.summary: Application Crash
